At that time, following the instructions of his spiritual benefactors, Sudhana went to the palace of the Thirty-three Celestials, the palace of the Heavenly King with perfect mindfulness, and saw the celestial maiden. He bowed at her feet, circumambulated her, joined his palms in front of her, and said:

The celestial maiden said:
Good man!

Sudhana said:
Holy One!
What is the scope of this liberation gate?

The goddess replied:
Good man!
Bodhisattvas diligently cultivate immeasurable and inconceivable Dharma gates to attain this liberation.
If you wish to enter this liberation gate, you should also diligently cultivate and study in this way.
What is diligently cultivating the inconceivable Dharma gates?
It is as follows:
You should diligently cultivate the wisdom of the inconceivable meaning of all dharmas;
That is, to truly awaken to the distinctions, natures, characteristics, and true essence of all dharmas.
You should diligently cultivate the protection of the true Dharma;
That is, to use reason to subdue and reveal the supreme meaning for those who slander the various wonderful Dharmas.
You should diligently cultivate the precepts of expression and non-expression;
That is, to minutely observe and not violate the precepts, whether natural or prohibited, with or without offenses.
You should diligently cultivate the Dharma of non-dispute;
It means to always stay far away from worldly affairs and idle chatter.
You should diligently cultivate the ground of patience;
It means to be able to endure various sufferings that afflict the body and mind.
You should diligently cultivate the ability to endure various objects;
It means not to be destroyed by slander, insults, enmity, or harm, and to always be patient.
You should diligently cultivate the understanding of subtle dharmas;
It means to know the aggregates, realms, and sense bases, their arising and cessation, and to skillfully understand their nature and characteristics as unobtainable.
You should diligently cultivate skillful Dharma phrases;
It means to be able to expound various Dharma gates with skillful means, causing the true nature and characteristics to be revealed.
You should diligently cultivate the combination and non-combination of dharmas;
It means to understand that the nature of dharmas is ungraspable, and is neither increased nor decreased, combined or separated.
You should diligently cultivate the wisdom of observing the past;
It means to be able to discern the various causes and effects of karma, good and bad, without fail.
You should diligently cultivate the wisdom of the future;
It means to be able to discern the various conditions and retributions of karma, without fail.
You should diligently cultivate equality in the three times;
It means that although the characteristics of the three times are different, they are only distinguished according to the abiding Dharma.
You should diligently cultivate the purification of the three wheels;
It means that the nature of all dharmas in the past, present, and future cannot be attained, because they are apart from mind and thought.
You should diligently cultivate the Dharma of the mind abiding in its place;
It means to universally understand that the characteristics of the mind, internally, externally, and in between, are fundamentally unobtainable.
You should diligently cultivate the guarding of deportment;
It means to minutely observe at all times, without confusion, the activities of body, speech, and mind.
You should diligently cultivate pure deportment;
It means to guard the sense-gates well, to conceal good dharmas, and to always confess unwholesome dharmas.
You should diligently cultivate the abandonment of unwholesome dharmas;
It means not to dwell with various evil dharmas of foolish ordinary beings, but to always be aware of them.
You should diligently cultivate the accumulation of bodhisattva practices;
It means to universally understand and courageously strive in various practices that are difficult to carry out.
You should diligently cultivate respect for elders;
It means to provide beds, seats, and offerings, to serve and welcome them, and to be humble in body and mind without laziness.
You should diligently cultivate the gathering and upholding of body and mind;
It means to be able to universally gather and uphold all pure dharmas, without losing or destroying them, always being aware of them.
You should diligently cultivate the following of the wisdom of enlightenment;
It means to be enlightened to the characteristics of all worldly and supramundane dharmas in accordance with their natures.
You should diligently cultivate the entry into profound dharmas;
It means penetrating the characteristics of all arising and ceasing phenomena, causing the mind to increase in the wisdom of non-arising.
You should diligently cultivate the wisdom of the Dharma of sound;
It means truly expounding various Dharma gates and revealing the true nature of language.
You should diligently cultivate the avoidance of what is unbeneficial;
It means using various skillful means to cause oneself and others to transcend all unbeneficial dharmas.
You should diligently cultivate the assembly of heroes;
It means always revering and serving the Buddhas, Bodhisattvas, Sravakas, and Pratyekabuddhas.
You should diligently cultivate the avoidance of evil friends;
It means avoiding those who delight in arising views of annihilation and permanence, as well as evil beings such as the lazy.
You should diligently cultivate not relying on ordinary beings;
It means seeing that the dharmas of ordinary beings are all associated with foolishness and many faults.
You should diligently cultivate a mind that is always not contemptuous;
It means understanding the equality of the nature of all beings, not giving rise to contempt for the poor and lowly.
You should diligently cultivate compassion for those who violate precepts;
It means using great compassion to rescue and liberate those who have committed offenses and establish them in the pure precepts of bodhisattvas.
You should diligently cultivate the power of increasing compassion;
It means observing the various afflictions of beings in the ten directions and three times and being able to rescue and protect them.
You should diligently cultivate the embracing of beings through wealth and the Dharma;
It means using wealth and goods to embrace all beings and cause them to enter the profound true Dharma.
You should diligently cultivate practicing in accordance with what is said;
It means cultivating various kinds of goodness to develop one's own mind, becoming replete and flourishing, and attaining completion.
You should diligently cultivate the goodness that accords with the past;
It means seeking the skillful means of the knowledge of past abodes and being able to know the practices that accord with the past.
You should diligently cultivate the goodness of joyfully being alone in tranquility;
That is, to stay far away from the mixed talk of the assembly and always delight in being close to the pure white dharmas.
You should diligently cultivate few desires and contentment;
That is, with regard to clothing, food and drink, bedding, and medicine, you should know how to be content with what you have yourself and what others teach you.
You should diligently cultivate the Dharma of corresponding practices;
That is, the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment, always diligently cultivating them and causing them to correspond.
You should diligently cultivate the realm of bodhisattva practice;
That is, the ten perfections and all the methods of practice, fully cultivating them and causing them to be perfected.
You should diligently cultivate the Dharma of the stages of the bodhisattvas;
That is, the ten kinds of cognition stages, entering, abiding, and the characteristics of emerging, as well as attaining the fruits, all of which should be realized and known.
You should diligently cultivate entering the stage of the TathÄgata;
That is, if it is the cognition of enlightenment and the various essences and functions that are eliminated, all of them should be realized and attained.

Sudhana said:
Sage!
How does one cultivate to attain this liberation?
She replied:
Good man!
If bodhisattvas diligently cultivate ten dharmas and perfect them, they will be able to attain this bodhisattva liberation of skillfully knowing the arts.
What are the ten?
They are:

Possessing wisdom, diligently seeking good friends, being courageous and vigorous, being free from the afflictions of hindrances, practicing pure conduct, respecting the true teachings, contemplating the emptiness of the nature of dharmas, eliminating wrong views, cultivating the right path, and possessing true wisdom.
If bodhisattvas perfect these ten dharmas, they will be able to quickly attain this liberation.
Why is it so?

Because bodhisattvas are endowed with wisdom, diligently seek good friends, and upon seeing them, draw near, rejoice, love and respect them, giving rise to the thought of them as buddhas. Because of drawing near, they always receive their teachings. Because of receiving their teachings, they are able to courageously and diligently practice what is difficult to practice.
Having attained diligence, they are able to use good dharmas to extinguish all that is not good.

Because of extinguishing unwholesomeness, it causes all wholesome dharmas to be perfected. Having perfected wholesomeness, one is able to completely avoid all afflictive hindrances. Because of avoiding hindrances, it causes body, speech, and mind to attain great purity. Correct practice is in accord with this purity. Because of this purity, one is able to give rise to respect for the teachings of all Buddhas, Bodhisattvas, and good and virtuous friends. Because of respecting the teachings, one diligently seeks to contemplate the emptiness and quiescence of all dharmas. Having realized the emptiness of dharmas, one's mind is unobstructed in all directions. Deeply penetrating dependent origination, one avoids the view of no cause. Destroying the mind of wrong views, one cultivates the correct path. Having entered the correct path, one attains true wisdom. Because of attaining true wisdom, one attains this liberation and realizes the profound Dharma realm.
Sudhana further said:

He replied:
Good man!

Sudhana further said:

He replied:
Good man!
Non-deceptive speech is called true.
He further said:

The master of arts replied:
That speech is true, its essence is always unchanging, because it is always of a single nature.
He further said:
What is meant by unchanging nature?
He replied:
Good man!
Because one personally realizes and understands the nature of dharmas.
He further said:

Is the dharma that is understood one or two?
He replied:
Good man!
In this way, the dharma that bodhisattvas personally realize is neither one nor two.
